Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence

Participants.evidence: tendon samples were obtained from 88 individuals (49 men, 39 women; mean age, 58.2 years) undergoing arthroscopic rotator cuff repair and five male patients (mean age, 69.6 years) who died of cardiovascular events

Intervention.evidence: Hematoxylin and eosin staining and Alcian blue were used to assess slides with Bonar and Movin scores

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to compare the reliability of these two scoring systems in evaluating tendon tissue

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC) between the two scoring systems, measured immediately post-surgery

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to the scoring system used

Number_Randomised.evidence: tendon samples were obtained from 88 individuals

Result_Outcome.evidence: The ICC was 0.921 (95% CI 0.790–0.963), indicating high reliability between the scoring systems
